comments.text:
The sleep schedule of an ADHD person.

Go to bed between 6:00 to 8:00 in the morning.

Wake up by 9:30 to 11 in the morning.

Make breakfast/lunch from scratch witch takes between 1 and 2 hours.

Clean then start on dinner. From scratch Also about 1 to 5 hours depending on whatever is made.

Then i work on writing my books while listening news videos/other videos until i get tired around 4 in the morning.

Then i lay down and toss and turn until i finally fall asleep around 6 to 8 in the morning.

Then before i wake up i can hear my brain telling itself that it is currently sleeping and if it is ready or not to actually open my eyes.

Which Then leads to me waking up fully rested from my brain julting my awake as i become completely aware of the fact that i was just sleeping.

And yes I do realize that he said without impairment.

But one what definition of impairment is he referring to?.

And two is he referring to any kind of impairment.

Because if that's the case then he's referring to every single.

Disabled person ever never being able to be fully functionally rested.

No matter how much sleep they have which is obviously factually incorrect.

So when you make a statement like that you should clarify. What you mean by impairment.

P.S. a drunk person is also impaired. No matter the amount of sleep that they may have had.

comments.text: So you guys can call bullshit if you want but this is my story and I'm sticking to it, no BS. I was a meth addict for 10 years, from 1985 to 1995 during that time I had several episodes where I would stay up for anywhere from 5 to 8 days in a row. I'm not going to try to lie or trick you into believing they didn't affect me, you bet your ass it did, psychologically emotionally physically it affected me. I got clean in 1995. I started college in 1996. I took a full load while working 25 hours a week. I won academic achievement awards and was on the president's list for all three years earning 108 credits while I did my associate's degree. I want a scholarship and a full ride to my bachelor's program. I also became morbidly obese and developed to sleep apnea. During that time I work 20 hours a week in the library carried a full load and averaged about 7 hours of sleep a night with sleep apnea so you can do the math there I was probably averaging 3 and 1/2 hours of sleep. Did it affect me? You bet it did. Nevertheless, I maintained a 3.93 GPA graduated summa cum laude and earned a full ride scholarship to my master's program while I was married and co-parenting three stepchildren. I entered my master's program still morbidly obese at well over 350 lbs. Fathered a child and maintain a 3.92 GPA while carrying a full load and classes and teaching four classes per term averaging less than 6 hours of sleep per night with sleep apnea when it finally under went a sleep study and was put on a CPAP machine which helped tremendously. I maintained my GPA at 3.92 retook my graduate record examination and earned a full ride scholarship to my PhD program While co-parenting three step children helping to raise my newborn daughter and matriculating through my master's program. I answered my PhD program at 390 lbs. Carrying a full load of courses teaching as a graduate teaching assistant maintaining a 3.91 GPA when I began to have panic attacks. Was the lack of sleep affecting me, yes it was was being married to a shrieking harpy affecting me, yes it was. Was being morbidly obese affecting me? Yes it was was being a closeted transgender individual for the previous 30 years affecting me Yes it was. Nevertheless I maintained my GPA got through my academic studies and took my graduate exams and passed had bariatric surgery and lost 140 lb got on medication for my panic attacks and got my dissertation prospectus approved and moved the family back to Oregon. Went through a divorce, couldn't find a job as a professor and became an entrepreneur worked 80 hours a week averaging 5 to 6 hours of sleep at night maximum for 9 years. Stop having a panic attacks though because I was no longer married to that shrinking harpie. Started a new business, work 80 hours a week to build that and after 3 years I began my transition and the 70 lb I had gained back I lost again and I've been averaging slightly less than 6 hours of sleep per night the whole time sure there are times when I sleep in but it's usually because I'm sick like with a severe cold or something but now I'm 60 years old and has the lack of sleep affected me I don't know maybe maybe not but I run two successful businesses I have a genius IQ I'm happy and we'll adjusted I have a memory that's as sharp as attack so you tell me, or some people just able to endure with less sleep than others. I think they are. But you got to follow your own path and listen to your body when it says rest, you better rest or you're going to pay for it. I'm slowing down now, I don't feel the urge desire or compulsion to only sleep 6 hours sometimes it's just works out that way. What's a girl going to do?

comments.text: Alright I'll explain how what he's saying could be wrong in some way. A person can sleep 7-9 hours and still wake up impaired because there's a specific time we should wake up at which is when the sleep cycle is over. A sleep cycle is 1.5 hours so if you sleep at 10 pm and wake up at 11:30 pm you will wake up feeling great. The same goes when you wake up at 3 hours of sleep or 4.5 or 6 or 7.5 or 9. However, of course everyone would sleep 1.5 hours if they're gonna wake up feeling great anyways. Well, the more sleep cycles you have the longer your "feeling great" state will last. If you sleep 1.5 hours you will be good for 2 hours then you will shut down. If you sleep 9 hours you'll stay fresh the whole day.

comments.text: There is a gene, I don‚Äôt remember what it was called, that they found which does account for why some people can effectively function on 4-5 hours of sleep. Probably because they are more efficient, they enter the most productive stage of the sleep cycle and get the same amount as most get in 8 hours so it‚Äôs not that they are getting less sleep it‚Äôs that they get that amount of that part of the cycle in less time than most people. However, I don‚Äôt think we still know if this is sustainable or not, meaning, if this changes with age since some genes do change and when you are 60 if this has chronic or acute byproducts due to say not getting as much of the other parts of the sleep cycle or simply not resting overall as much. It‚Äôs very hard to know for sure. In general though I agree with this guy, almost nobody can escape the short or long term damage from sleep deprivation but the info I expressed is the one potential caveat. Key word, ‚Äúpotential,‚Äù not certain

You can have less than 6 hours of sleep, but various important chemicals will have impaired production.

Just for an example, supposedly, sleep deprivation can raise Ghrelin levels while lowering Leptin levels. This makes it very difficult to tell whether or not you're full or hungry.

Several studies have also linked a lack of sleep with increased rates of headaches and migraines.

There are also around a couple dozen equally important facets to basic human health which become impaired due to a lack of sleep.

comments.text: I honestly don't sleep more than 5 hours per night (not by choice, but due to insomnia) And I have done this for the last 10 years. All my bloodwork is fine. Can't say for sure I'm not taking any harm as far as neurological problems etc. goes. But I feel fine for the most part with 5 hours of sleep. Some nights I only sleep 3 hours too. There's definitely a huge difference in how well you function due to how well you've slept and for how long you've slept. In the odd chance I get a full night of sleep 6-7 hours I feel fantastic compared to 4-5 hours. Before I used to get worried when I got little sleep as I felt I couldn't function properly at work etc. but as I've gotten used to it over the years I don't really care about terrible nights anymore. I do my important stuff early and go to bed early in the evening instead. And no matter how tired and destroyed I feel I've learned that physical exercise like walking/jogging always makes you feel better.

comments.text:
Um. This guy doesn't know what hes talking about. I sleep without an alarm. I wake up when i wake up. Theres litterally 0 pressure for me to wake up when i do. I generally sleep 5.5 to 6.5 hours per night. With a little over 6 probably more common. I couldn't sleep 8 if i tried. It's literally impossible for me to do it. I have no impairments.

I used an alarm when i was a kid. Then i realized theres no point. I cannot actually sleep late enough to miss anything of importance. I cannot over sleep because to do it id have to stay up to like 4 in the morning and i don't do that. So i stopped using an alarm. Except for very rare cases. And im not conditioned to wake up at a certain time. If i go to bed early for whatever reason.. again.. ill wake up earlier. If i go to sleep at 8pm. Im waking up around 2-3am. I get the amount of sleep my body needs. I dont see a need to try to reduce it. And i have absolutely no idea how i could increase it. Otherwise than tranquilizers. I just physically can't.

So theres at least one. Me. And i know im not the only one. So hes just wrong.

comments.author: @budgetarms
comments.text:
Lets see how many people who can SURVIVE with 6 hours of sleep or less WITHOUT showing impairment.

Population today: 7.888 billion (10^9).
And the percentage is "when rounding the number, it is 0 percent".
In math when you round 0.4999... it also comes out as 0 percent.
Lets take the closest rounded number with one decimal, that is 0.5 percent.
From percent to a real number is percentage dividing by 100, so 0.5/100 = 0.005 or 5 * 10^(-3).

7.888 * 10^9 * 5 * 10^(-3) = 39,440,000 or written in scientific notation 3.944 * 10^7.
That is 39.44 million people.

That are a lot of people, and we dont even know the specifications of how they formulated showing impairment.
E.g: Is having a slower reaction time included as an impairment?

I can go on and on, but we all know that not sleeping or not having enough sleep is bad.
That is a fact.

Okey so the thing with this subjects is making a difference between being in bed with your eyes shut , and actually being asleep.
Specially in the REM phase.
I su ally lay down at around 1:30 am
And wake up at 8am every day.
That‚Äôs 6:30 hours of sleep every day.
And I am super energetic, why?
I‚Äôm super active during the day , I go to bed tired , and I have a rule to avoid instagram , WhatsApp, YouTube , tik tok during my last hour before going to bed.
A tv series , a book a movie or even just walking the dog is the way I close my day.
So when I touch that bed I‚Äôm K.O in less than 10 min.
And usually it is goodby till the next day.

I know many people , my sister an my teenage nephew between them , that ‚Äúsleep‚Äù close to 10 hours a day.
But they start thinking about a lot of stuff when they close their eyes.
They wake up and go to the bathroom 2 times per night , it takes them quite a while to get asleep when they lay down , and once again each time they wake up. Between different things , they are lucky if they are spending 2 whole hours of REM sleep.

comments.author: @PhatesDemise
comments.text: To the people who for some reason can‚Äôt understand. Most people have a couple nights of 5 hours of sleep. It‚Äôs fine. It might cause slight performance issues but not noticeable. The key words are survive and with 0 impairment. Getting 1-3 5 hour sleep nights won‚Äôt kill you. Doing it for 3 months straight with 0 naps and 0 8 hour sleep days will decimate pretty much anyone. There have been so many studies at this point on sleep deprivation that it blows my mind people think they are the special outlier. If you are volunteer for a sleep deprivation study and you will realize how untrue that is after 3 months on no more than 5 monitored hours of sleep per day. Recently had a dude who claimed he slept 5-6 hours of sleep per day. He did a study. It turns out his avg sleep was 7 hours per day. He would sleep 5 hours a day 5 days a week and 8-10 hours on his days off work. After 3 weeks into the study he quit.

comments.text:
I'm like this (and not in a ''I'm so hardcore way") - I have an 18 month old daughter and work 7am-8pm shifts 3-4x per week, so when I'm at work I don't sleep before 1-2am because it's 'wasting time', so 6 hours would be a GOOD sleep, and on my days off I never make up for it because my daughter is up but often stay up even later 2-3am.

I've been like this since I was 14-15 and falling asleep in school, so half my life at this point. When I get home it's not uncommon to nap still in my work stuff in random places, or even sat on the toilet half napping at work, yet I can't change because my brain tells me ''why sleep at 10-11pm when that's 'wasting' 2+ hours every single day?"

I guess the quality of the time I am awake isn't optimal so maybe even just chilling or hobbies would feel better if I'd slept more? Kinda trips me out thinking this whole time I could have felt completely different but just never knew it
